parts.text: The Oklahoma House passed legislation this week intended to encourage faith-based and
other volunteer groups to help reintegrate inmates back into society.
Speaker Lance Cargill is the author of House Bill, 2101.
He hopes the proposal will help Oklahoma move away from a warehousing mentality that often
helps create better criminals because of lessons they learn while behind bars.
The Reverend Stan Basler is the director of Criminal Justice and Immersive Ministries
for the United Methodist Church in Oklahoma.
He believes this bill could help keep criminals from returning to prison once they're released.
Basler said the legislation could shore up the church's efforts by coordinating faith-based
programs, including parenting courses.
You know, a redemption charge here in Oklahoma City of congregation of prisoners, ex-prisoners,
their families, and their religious volunteers.
We do teach the common sense parenting class.
We have depended on volunteers and that has occurred intermittently.
We have also, at times, had the clinching the fatherhood thirst, which is a fatherhood
initiative class.
Again, we have not sustained that as well as we would like.
But I think the idea of emphasizing parenting classes with prisoners who are in fact
parents is very appropriate and a good idea.
One of prison fellowships statistics, and again, I don't have to verify the issues that
95 percent of the men in prison had no loving father figure as a role model.
And along with the statistics that show that children with incarcerated parents have
a much higher criminal offense rate than other children, all of that suggests it would
be a better world, I think, if parenting skills were enhanced.
Basler believes it takes more than good programs to change prisoners' lives.
It won't be possible to get everybody involved in the programs.
We believe, apparently, the speaker does, that it is God who changes hearts and in behaviors
and that a faith-based approach, a sincere one, is the most likely path to lasting change.
But there are some real physical needs that are there as well.
People coming out of prison many times have little money, no job, no transportation,
no housing, challenges to get a driver's license reinstrated, sometimes not a lot of skills
to get a job.
They're often faced with having to pay court costs back to child support and a variety
of financial obligations that all communicate to a sense of hopelessness that in fact they
can make it on the outside.
There's room for a lot of different ministries in this field to address the various different
needs that people have and to create various kinds of communities, not everybody gravitates
to the same place of community, but there's room for a number of pro-social communities
to try to assimilate these people when they come out.
And not all of them have to be faith-based, learning how to deal with leisure time with
little or no money is also an important area.
So bridge clubs, softball leagues, a number of things could be involved in this effort.
A similar bill also passed the House last session, but failed in the Senate.
Bastler said House Bill 2101 looks like it might have a better fate.
Actually, some of the things that appeared in the Senate amendments appear to be in this
bill.
I think a good distillation of perhaps some of the best ideas from last year have been
in a more tightly focused form.
The State Senate will now consider the speaker's proposal.
For KGOU News, I'm Kurt Gwartney.
